JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
VOL. XVIII, NO.

12.

BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 19, 1914.

SOME PHASES OF THE WAR

DUAL MEET ON JANUARY 31

Dr. Charles F. Adams to Lecture First
of Series of Eight Will Take Place
in McCoy Hall Thursday.

Track Team to . Compete With Milton
University Gailey of St. John's and
Pulford of Trinity Join Squad.

Eight lectures, the general subject of which is "1843-1865. A Nationality: Its Inception; Its Development; Its Birth," are to be
given in McCoy Hall, beginning
Thursday, January 22, at 5 P. M.,
by Charles Francis Adams, LL.D.,
of Boston.
Dr. Adams is well known as an
historical writer and publicist, having published: "Three Episodes of
Massachusetts History"; Massachu7
setts, Its Historians and Its History"; Lee at Appomattox," and
many other papers of note. For
six years he was president of the
Union Pacific Railroad, and in 1895
became president of the Massachusetts Historical Society. Besides
this he served in the Civil War,
becoming colonel of cavalry, and
brevet brigadier-general U. S. A.
No cards of admission will be
required to the lectures of which
the specific topics and dates are as
follows:
Thursday, January 22—"Principia."
Tuesday, January 27—"The Pitfall of a Divided Sovereignty."
Thursday, February 5 — "King
Cotton."
Thursday, February 12—"The.
Lancashire Armageddon."
Thursday, February 19—"British
Civil War Cartoons."
Thursday, February 26—"A Crisis
in Downing Street."
Thursday, March 5—"Expende
Hannibalem."
Thursday, March I2—Vx Victis ;
and Reconstruction."

\\-ith a dual meet scheduled with
Milton University for January 31,
the track team will soon be given
an opportunity to display its true
form. The hard and steady practices of the last few weeks are developing a:squad that certainly demands commendation. Although it
is impossible at this stage of the
game to predict the outcome, prospects are surely good. The squad
now numbers about sixty men.
There have been two recent additions—Gailey, of St. John's, who
runs the quarter mile; and Pulford.
who took honors for Trinity College last year in the pole vaulting
contest. It is interesting to note
that in no previous year has the
number of men out for track been
as large, at this time of the year,
as the present squad.
It will be some time before the
coach can say anything positive
about the team.
Manager Dorsey is still busy
completing the schedule, the full
data of which will be given out
soon.
Those out for track are: Astor,
'Beck, Binford, Blanco, Brower,
Catlin, Chesley, Cohn, Darlet, Davis, Defandorf, Fankhanel, Frank,
Gailey, Gichner, Green, Groover,
E. G. Hall, F. P. Hall, Hardy,
Hayes, Houghton, Hutton, Iddings,
Jacobs, Jackson, Kendall, Lasinsky,
Lloyd, Lynch, McDowell, McKener,
Melamet, Merrick, Penniman, Pitt,
Perkins, Pulford, Rosenthal, Rusk,
Spencer, Steinback, Stiebel, Straus,
Tappan, Thompson, Twigg, Uhler,
Del Valle, Wagner, Webb-Peploe,
Weech,Watson, Weis, Wells, White
and Young. .
Rev. George Evans Smith, the
new president of the George R.
Smith College, Sedalia, Mo., was
a graduate student in the classical
languages at Johns Hopkins in the
years 1902-3. For the past year
he has been taking special work at
the University.
A marriage of much interest to
the older Hopkins men took place
on January io last, when Mr. John
Leypold Griffith Lee, A. B.'93, was
married to Miss Caroline Webster
Hunter at Emnianuel Church, Belair, Md.
William E. Pearce, A. B. '07,
Ph. D. '13, is now a member of the
faculty of the Baltimore City College. He takes the place of Prof.
Alexander Hamilton, resigned, who
is •well known to many Hopkins
men.

French Lecturer to Come.

M. Fernand Baldensperger, professor of comparative literature at
the University .of Lyons, will deliver
a lecture in English on "French
Enthusiasm About America, 17701789." This lecture, which, coming from a man who has made a
deep study of his subject, will undoubtedly prove interesting, especially to students of history and
international relations. It is scheduled to. take place in McCoy Hall
on Wednesday, February 4, at five
o'clock.
George Ross Veazey, A. B. 'to, a
former editor-in-chief of THE
NEWS-LETTER and who, after his
graduation, spent several years in
the political science 'department, is
now practicing law in this city. His
office is in the Fidelity Building.
Until recently Mr. Veazey was with
the Fidelity and Deposit Company.

INTERCLASS MEET
WON BY FRESHIES
Great Crowd Sees Class of 1917 Win
Track Laurels in Hopkins Cage
Saturday — Events Are
Hotly Contested.

In the presence of one of the
largest crowds that has ever been
within the cage, the annual freshman-sophomore track meet was run
off in a most successful manner on
Saturday, and 1917 won by the
score of 40 to 29.
The feature of the day was, undoubtedly, the work of George
Penniman, who starred in a brilliant
manner for the sophs. With first
place in the 30-yard dash and in the
broad jump, and second in the
hurdles, he contributed 13 points
to his team's total. In the first heat
of the 30- yard dash Penniman
equalled the cage record of 3.,y
seconds.
Other men who also deserve especial notice. are: Binford, who won
three seconds for the freshmen in
a most clever manner; Brooks, who
won the shot put with ease and who
also showed to advantage in the
30-yard dash; Hall and Gorman,
winners of the half and the mile, respectively; and Captain Melamet of
the sophs, who ran a wonderful race
in the quarter.
The feature event, from the spectator's standpoint, however, was the
senior-junior relay race. This was
most exciting and drew great applause. The juniors repeated their
success of two years ago when,
as freshmen, they defeated 1914.
The sophomore-freshmen race was
easily won by 1917.
The meet started with the heats
of the 30-yard dash, which were all
fast and closely contested. The
second event was the high jump,
and in it the sophs drew first blood,
Nelson and Iddings tying at 5 feet
4 inches. They increased their lead
when Penniman captured the 30yard event immediately afterward.
The fourth event was the 44o.
Melamet drew the pole and kept
the lead from the start, although
Binford made several game efforts
to pass him. The sophs were now
leading by a score of 18 to 6.
The freshies pulled up considerably, however, in the shot put,
which was the next event; Brooks
and Kaiser taking first and second,
respectively. The sixth event was
the 88o-yard run. Hall took the
lead at the start, with Straus, WebbPeploe, Hayes and Hutton following in thc,order named. Hall was
running easily and Hutton appeared
to be taking his time. This continued for the first six laps, when

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

DR. WEATHERFORD'S LECTURE
He Urges Men of Power and Strength in
College to Stand for Right
Against Odds.

Dr. \\ catherford, student X. .\ I.
C. A., Secretary of the South, on
Wednesday and Friday of last week,
gave two straight-from-the-shoulder talks to the undergraduate body.
Before his talk on Wednesday,
a light lunch was served by the Association, consisting of sandwiches,
cocoa, oranges and Wagnerian cake.
Dr. Brush introduced Dr. Weatherford, who spoke on the inability
of a man to make good without the
power of a clean life behind him.
The talk on Thursday was postponed to Friday, at twelve, to avoid
conflicting with Dr. Lomax.
Dr. Weatherford, in his final talk,
urged the men of power and
strength in college to stand up for
the right, no matter against what
odds—to become pillars of strength
around which their weaker fellows
might rally. He enlivened his talk
by instances from actual college
life. His practical advice will be
gratefully remembered by all the
men who heard him.
During his stay in Baltimore, Dr.
Weatherford visited several of the
Hopkins fraternities, where he was
able to talk to the men in a more
intimate and personal way than
from the platform.
riutton, with a splendid spurt,
pulled up to second. From then on
he and Hall easily outdistanced the
others. Both finished strong, Hall
leading by 15 yards. The 30-yard
hurdles, which followed, was fast
and close; Fulton just nosing Penniman out. The score was now tied
(24 to 24) and the crowd was much
excited.
The sophs went ahead by two
points in the broad jump; Penniman beating Binford by about half
a foot. The mile run, which followed, decided the meet however,
for the freshmen won both places.
it was a most interesting race. For
the first 12 laps the lead see-sawed
between Beck, Niles and Weech,
with the others in a bunch. About
then Gorman and Hall began to
pull up and came within easy striking distance of the leaders. Hayes
and Read were also near the front
and running well. On the fifteenth
lap Hayes jumped into first, with
Niles and. Weech following. Beck
was fast dropping back. On the
seventeenth lap Gorman and Hall
began to sprint and Weech was the
only one of the early leaders who
could stand the pace. Neck and
neck these three raced toward the

The cage record for the 1,600yard relay was broken on Wednesday evening when Capt. Milton
Wagner, Herbert Catlin, Huntly
Lloyd and G. L. Groover covered
the distance in 3 minutes 29 seconds. This time is 3 seconds better
than that made by E. I. Gunz, J. E.
England, C. L. Stone and J. S.
Hill on March 14, 1904, whose time
was 3 minutes 323.5 seconds, but
will not stand as a record because
the feat was not accomplished in
a scheduled meet.
The fact that these four runners
bettered the old record when none
of them were in condition only goes
further to reverberate the statement
of the coach that Hopkins this year
will be represented by a first-rate
track team.

were the favorite weapons used by

Smith and Brent. The whole Senate showed great interest in the
progress and result of the debate."

Bureau of Appointments.

The Bureau of Appointments
wishes to make it known to the
graduating students of 1914 that
it is prepared to enroll all who wish
to be considered applicants for positions of any particular kind. This
Bureau handles all requests which
come directly to the University, but
not those which come to individual
instructors or'departments. But it
would be glad to enroll all students,
nevertheless, that it may have a
complete file of the graduates of
the University who are out at work.
The Bureau wishes to keep in continual touch with graduates that it
may, if possible, help them to other
or better positions, as the years go
by.
The Director of the Bureau can
be found in Room 25, third floor,
McCoy. Hall, any day between 12
and i o'clock.
R. V. D. MAGOVVIN,
Director Bureau of Appointments.

The summary:

Smokers, Beware!

Dr. Kelly says pipes and cigarettes give you cancer of the lip, as
witness the following from the
New York Journal:
"A very large percentage of radium being sold is a fake," Dr.
Howard A. Kelly, the famous radium expert of ,Baltimore, declared
in an address before the Bible
Teachers' Training School, No. 541
Lexington avenue. "Recently," he
continued, "I purchased two tubes
and found that one contained only
one-fifth of a milligram, the other
one-tenth of a milligram. Real
radium the size of a pea is valued
at $125,000.
"There is no question in my mind
but that radium will extend surgery
in the field of cancer. It will not
cure all cases, but it will cure a
great many.
"I am working to get enough
radium to test thoroughly its possibilities. It is my hope that I may
aid in putting it at a price that will
be within the means of all.
"Cancer in many cases is caused
by immorality or filth. It is immoral for men to burn their bodies,
yet in the large majority of cases
cancer of the lip is due to men
smoking short pipes and burning
cigars to the butt. No man has a
right to be an inveterate smoker.

Would Eat Himself for $25.

A stalwart young German applied
for a position on a farm. As he
walked into the barn he addressed
the farmer: "Hey, mister, will you
job me?"
"Will I what?"
"Will you job me? Make me
work yet."
"Oh, I see; you want a job," said
the farmer. "Well, how much do
you want a month.
• "I tell you. If you eat me on der
farm, I come for $5. but for $25 I
eat myself at Schmidt's."—National
Food Magazine.

BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 19, 1914.

SOME PHASES OF THE WAR

DUAL MEET ON JANUARY 31

Dr. Charles F. Adams to Lecture First
of Series of Eight Will Take Place
in McCoy Hall Thursday.

Track Team to . Compete With Milton
University Gailey of St. John's and
Pulford of Trinity Join Squad.

Eight lectures, the general subject of which is "1843-1865. A Nationality: Its Inception; Its Development; Its Birth," are to be
given in McCoy Hall, beginning
Thursday, January 22, at 5 P. M.,
by Charles Francis Adams, LL.D.,
of Boston.
Dr. Adams is well known as an
historical writer and publicist, having published: "Three Episodes of
Massachusetts History"; Massachu7
setts, Its Historians and Its History"; Lee at Appomattox," and
many other papers of note. For
six years he was president of the
Union Pacific Railroad, and in 1895
became president of the Massachusetts Historical Society. Besides
this he served in the Civil War,
becoming colonel of cavalry, and
brevet brigadier-general U. S. A.
No cards of admission will be
required to the lectures of which
the specific topics and dates are as
follows:
Thursday, January 22—"Principia."
Tuesday, January 27—"The Pitfall of a Divided Sovereignty."
Thursday, February 5 — "King
Cotton."
Thursday, February 12—"The.
Lancashire Armageddon."
Thursday, February 19—"British
Civil War Cartoons."
Thursday, February 26—"A Crisis
in Downing Street."
Thursday, March 5—"Expende
Hannibalem."
Thursday, March I2—Vx Victis ;
and Reconstruction."

\\-ith a dual meet scheduled with
Milton University for January 31,
the track team will soon be given
an opportunity to display its true
form. The hard and steady practices of the last few weeks are developing a:squad that certainly demands commendation. Although it
is impossible at this stage of the
game to predict the outcome, prospects are surely good. The squad
now numbers about sixty men.
There have been two recent additions—Gailey, of St. John's, who
runs the quarter mile; and Pulford.
who took honors for Trinity College last year in the pole vaulting
contest. It is interesting to note
that in no previous year has the
number of men out for track been
as large, at this time of the year,
as the present squad.
It will be some time before the
coach can say anything positive
about the team.
Manager Dorsey is still busy
completing the schedule, the full
data of which will be given out
soon.
Those out for track are: Astor,
'Beck, Binford, Blanco, Brower,
Catlin, Chesley, Cohn, Darlet, Davis, Defandorf, Fankhanel, Frank,
Gailey, Gichner, Green, Groover,
E. G. Hall, F. P. Hall, Hardy,
Hayes, Houghton, Hutton, Iddings,
Jacobs, Jackson, Kendall, Lasinsky,
Lloyd, Lynch, McDowell, McKener,
Melamet, Merrick, Penniman, Pitt,
Perkins, Pulford, Rosenthal, Rusk,
Spencer, Steinback, Stiebel, Straus,
Tappan, Thompson, Twigg, Uhler,
Del Valle, Wagner, Webb-Peploe,
Weech,Watson, Weis, Wells, White
and Young. .
Rev. George Evans Smith, the
new president of the George R.
Smith College, Sedalia, Mo., was
a graduate student in the classical
languages at Johns Hopkins in the
years 1902-3. For the past year
he has been taking special work at
the University.
A marriage of much interest to
the older Hopkins men took place
on January io last, when Mr. John
Leypold Griffith Lee, A. B.'93, was
married to Miss Caroline Webster
Hunter at Emnianuel Church, Belair, Md.
William E. Pearce, A. B. '07,
Ph. D. '13, is now a member of the
faculty of the Baltimore City College. He takes the place of Prof.
Alexander Hamilton, resigned, who
is •well known to many Hopkins
men.

French Lecturer to Come.

M. Fernand Baldensperger, professor of comparative literature at
the University .of Lyons, will deliver
a lecture in English on "French
Enthusiasm About America, 17701789." This lecture, which, coming from a man who has made a
deep study of his subject, will undoubtedly prove interesting, especially to students of history and
international relations. It is scheduled to. take place in McCoy Hall
on Wednesday, February 4, at five
o'clock.
George Ross Veazey, A. B. 'to, a
former editor-in-chief of THE
NEWS-LETTER and who, after his
graduation, spent several years in
the political science 'department, is
now practicing law in this city. His
office is in the Fidelity Building.
Until recently Mr. Veazey was with
the Fidelity and Deposit Company.

INTERCLASS MEET
WON BY FRESHIES
Great Crowd Sees Class of 1917 Win
Track Laurels in Hopkins Cage
Saturday — Events Are
Hotly Contested.

In the presence of one of the
largest crowds that has ever been
within the cage, the annual freshman-sophomore track meet was run
off in a most successful manner on
Saturday, and 1917 won by the
score of 40 to 29.
The feature of the day was, undoubtedly, the work of George
Penniman, who starred in a brilliant
manner for the sophs. With first
place in the 30-yard dash and in the
broad jump, and second in the
hurdles, he contributed 13 points
to his team's total. In the first heat
of the 30- yard dash Penniman
equalled the cage record of 3.,y
seconds.
Other men who also deserve especial notice. are: Binford, who won
three seconds for the freshmen in
a most clever manner; Brooks, who
won the shot put with ease and who
also showed to advantage in the
30-yard dash; Hall and Gorman,
winners of the half and the mile, respectively; and Captain Melamet of
the sophs, who ran a wonderful race
in the quarter.
The feature event, from the spectator's standpoint, however, was the
senior-junior relay race. This was
most exciting and drew great applause. The juniors repeated their
success of two years ago when,
as freshmen, they defeated 1914.
The sophomore-freshmen race was
easily won by 1917.
The meet started with the heats
of the 30-yard dash, which were all
fast and closely contested. The
second event was the high jump,
and in it the sophs drew first blood,
Nelson and Iddings tying at 5 feet
4 inches. They increased their lead
when Penniman captured the 30yard event immediately afterward.
The fourth event was the 44o.
Melamet drew the pole and kept
the lead from the start, although
Binford made several game efforts
to pass him. The sophs were now
leading by a score of 18 to 6.
The freshies pulled up considerably, however, in the shot put,
which was the next event; Brooks
and Kaiser taking first and second,
respectively. The sixth event was
the 88o-yard run. Hall took the
lead at the start, with Straus, WebbPeploe, Hayes and Hutton following in thc,order named. Hall was
running easily and Hutton appeared
to be taking his time. This continued for the first six laps, when

DR. WEATHERFORD'S LECTURE
He Urges Men of Power and Strength in
College to Stand for Right
Against Odds.

Dr. \\ catherford, student X. .\ I.
C. A., Secretary of the South, on
Wednesday and Friday of last week,
gave two straight-from-the-shoulder talks to the undergraduate body.
Before his talk on Wednesday,
a light lunch was served by the Association, consisting of sandwiches,
cocoa, oranges and Wagnerian cake.
Dr. Brush introduced Dr. Weatherford, who spoke on the inability
of a man to make good without the
power of a clean life behind him.
The talk on Thursday was postponed to Friday, at twelve, to avoid
conflicting with Dr. Lomax.
Dr. Weatherford, in his final talk,
urged the men of power and
strength in college to stand up for
the right, no matter against what
odds—to become pillars of strength
around which their weaker fellows
might rally. He enlivened his talk
by instances from actual college
life. His practical advice will be
gratefully remembered by all the
men who heard him.
During his stay in Baltimore, Dr.
Weatherford visited several of the
Hopkins fraternities, where he was
able to talk to the men in a more
intimate and personal way than
from the platform.
riutton, with a splendid spurt,

The cage record for the 1,600yard relay was broken on Wednesday evening when Capt. Milton
Wagner, Herbert Catlin, Huntly
Lloyd and G. L. Groover covered
the distance in 3 minutes 29 seconds. This time is 3 seconds better
than that made by E. I. Gunz, J. E.
England, C. L. Stone and J. S.
Hill on March 14, 1904, whose time
was 3 minutes 323.5 seconds, but
will not stand as a record because
the feat was not accomplished in
a scheduled meet.
The fact that these four runners
bettered the old record when none
of them were in condition only goes
further to reverberate the statement
of the coach that Hopkins this year
will be represented by a first-rate
track team.

Bureau of Appointments.

The Bureau of Appointments
wishes to make it known to the
graduating students of 1914 that
it is prepared to enroll all who wish
to be considered applicants for positions of any particular kind. This
Bureau handles all requests which
come directly to the University, but
not those which come to individual
instructors or'departments. But it
would be glad to enroll all students,
nevertheless, that it may have a
complete file of the graduates of
the University who are out at work.
The Bureau wishes to keep in continual touch with graduates that it
may, if possible, help them to other
or better positions, as the years go
by.
The Director of the Bureau can
be found in Room 25, third floor,
McCoy. Hall, any day between 12
and i o'clock.
R. V. D. MAGOVVIN,
Director Bureau of Appointments.

The summary:

Smokers, Beware!

Dr. Kelly says pipes and cigarettes give you cancer of the lip, as
witness the following from the
New York Journal:
"A very large percentage of radium being sold is a fake," Dr.
Howard A. Kelly, the famous radium expert of ,Baltimore, declared
in an address before the Bible
Teachers' Training School, No. 541
Lexington avenue. "Recently," he
continued, "I purchased two tubes
and found that one contained only
one-fifth of a milligram, the other
one-tenth of a milligram. Real
radium the size of a pea is valued
at $125,000.
"There is no question in my mind
but that radium will extend surgery
in the field of cancer. It will not
cure all cases, but it will cure a
great many.
"I am working to get enough
radium to test thoroughly its possibilities. It is my hope that I may
aid in putting it at a price that will
be within the means of all.
"Cancer in many cases is caused
by immorality or filth. It is immoral for men to burn their bodies,
yet in the large majority of cases
cancer of the lip is due to men
smoking short pipes and burning
cigars to the butt. No man has a
right to be an inveterate smoker.

Would Eat Himself for $25.

A stalwart young German applied
for a position on a farm. As he
walked into the barn he addressed
the farmer: "Hey, mister, will you
job me?"
"Will I what?"
"Will you job me? Make me
work yet."
"Oh, I see; you want a job," said
the farmer. "Well, how much do
you want a month.
• "I tell you. If you eat me on der
farm, I come for $5. but for $25 I
eat myself at Schmidt's."—National
Food Magazine.
